com.yahoo.bullet.storm

Class SpoutConnector<T extends org.apache.storm.topology.IRichSpout>

  • java.lang.Object
    • com.yahoo.bullet.dsl.connector.BulletConnector
      • com.yahoo.bullet.storm.SpoutConnector<T>
  • Type Parameters:
    T - The type of the spout being composed.
    All Implemented Interfaces:
    Serializable, AutoCloseable, org.apache.storm.ICredentialsListener, org.apache.storm.spout.ISpout, org.apache.storm.topology.IComponent, org.apache.storm.topology.IRichSpout

    public abstract class SpoutConnector<T extends org.apache.storm.topology.IRichSpout>
extends com.yahoo.bullet.dsl.connector.BulletConnector
implements org.apache.storm.topology.IRichSpout, org.apache.storm.ICredentialsListener
    This is a BulletConnector that can also work as a IRichSpout that can also optionally implement the ICredentialsListener interface. It wraps a spout and proxies the various calls to it. The spout being composed must have a constructor that accepts a BulletConfig unless you override the getSpout() method. There are multiple ways to use this class but not all methods can be used in the same situation: 1. BulletConnector in the DSLSpout - This is if you have a IRichSpout that can be wrapped into SpoutConnector but you also need to plug in more DSL components like an existing BulletRecordConverter or a BulletDeserializer (in a separate bolt or not). In this case, you must implement the BulletConnector.read() method to transfer data from your spout. The DSL spout will not invoke the nextTuple() method and rely on BulletConnector.read() to read and pass the read objects to the rest of the DSL infrastructure. It will not invoke the initialize() method and instead call the activate() and the open(Map, TopologyContext, SpoutOutputCollector) in the appropriate methods in the spout. The DSLSpout will also invoke the ICredentialsListener interface if necessary. 2. BulletConnector elsewhere - This is if you want to use the SpoutConnector in any other context. In this case, the initialize() method will call ISpout.open(Map, TopologyContext, SpoutOutputCollector) and ISpout.activate() on the spout. You can use the #setContext(TopologyContext), #setOutputCollector(SpoutOutputCollector) and #setStormConfiguration(Map) to pass in those arguments to the open. The close() will invoke the ISpout.deactivate() method on the call. You should override the BulletConnector.read() method to actually do the transfer of the data from the spout as above. 3. IRichSpout - This is largely for testing or if you just want to use the connector as a IRichSpout. It would just behave as a proxy to the underlying spout in that case. The ICredentialsListener interface is also implemented if necessary. The getSpout() method is called on construction to create the composed spout. By default, it uses the BulletStormConfig.DSL_SPOUT_CONNECTOR_CLASS_NAME from the BulletConfig and reflection to load the spout. You may override it if you need a more elaborate creation mechanism.
    See Also:

      • getSpout

        protected T getSpout()
        Creates an instance of the composed spout. By default, uses the config to get the BulletStormConfig.DSL_SPOUT_CONNECTOR_CLASS_NAME and reflection to initialize an instance of the spout. The provided class must have a constructor that accepts a BulletConfig.
        Returns:
        The created spout.
